lg.l: The Life of Man to represent, And turn it all to ridicule;
Wit did a Poppit Show invent,Where the chief Actor is a Fool.2
The Gods of old were Logs of Wood, And worship was to Poppits pay'd,
In antick dress the Idol stood,And Priests & People bow'd the head.3
No wonder than if Art began The simple Votaries to frame;
To shape in Timber foolish Man,And consecrate the Block to Fame.4
From hence Poetick fancy learn'd That Trees might rise from human Forms,
The Body to a Trunk be turn'd,And branches issue from the arms.5
Thus Dabalus 1two famous Writers. & Ovid tooThat Man's a Blockhead have confest,
Powel 2two famous Masters of Poppit Shows. & Stretch the hint pursue,Life is a Farce, the World a Iest.6
The same great truth South Sea has prov'd,On that damn'd Theatre the Alley,
Where thousands by Directors mov'dAre now sad monuments of Folly.7
What Momus was of old to Iove, The same a Harlequin is now,
The former was buffoon'd above,The latter is a Punch below.8
This fleeting Scene is but a Stage, Where various images appear,
In different parts of youth & age,Alike the Prince & Peasant share.9
Some draw our eyes by being great, False Pomp conceals mere wood within,
And Legislators rang'd in stateAre oft but Wisdom in Machine.10
A Stock may chance to wear a Crown, And Timber, as a Lord, take place,
A Statue may put on a Frown,And cheat us with a thinking face.11
Others are blindly led away, And made to act for ends unknown,
By the mere spring of Wits they play,And speak in language not their own.12
Too oft, alass! a scolding Wife Usurps a jolly Fellow's throne,
And many drink the Cup of Life,Mix'd & embitter'd by a Ione.13
In short, whatever men pursue Of pleasure, folly, or of Love,
This mimickÂ·race brings all to view,Alike they dress, they talk, they move.14
Go on, great Stretch, with artfull hand Mortals to please, & to deride,
And when Death breaks thy vital Band,Thou shalt put on the Poppit's pride.15
Thou shalt in Puny wood be shewn, Thy image shall preserve thy fame,
Ages to come thy worth shall own,Point at thy limbs, & tell thy name.16
Tell Tom he draws a farce in vain, Before he looks in Nature's glass,
Punns cannot form a witty scene,Nor Pageantry for Honour pass.17
To make men act as senseless wood, And chatter in a mistick strain,
Is a mere farce on flesh & blood,And shews some error in the brain.18
He that would thus refine on thee, And turn thy Stage into a school,
The best of Punch shall ever be,And stand confest the greater fool.Y03-315A
